faq.title: Compatibility with &xslt4j; version 1
faq.q: How do I run applications that use the &xslt4j; version 1 API with &xslt4j2;

a.p: Use the Xalan-Java 1 compatibility JAR to recompile and run your &xslt4j; 1 applications with &xslt4j2;. For more information, see Using the &xslt4j; version 1 API.

faq.title: TrAX and JAXP
faq.q: What are TrAX and JAXP, and are they related?

a.p: TrAX is the Transformation API for XML. In November 2000, TrAX was revised and incorporated into JAXP, the JAVA API for XML Processing. JAXP (including TrAX) provides users a standard, vendor-neutral API for working with (and transforming) XML documents. You can use this API to build applications that are not bound to the particular implementation details of a given XML parser or XSL transformer.

&xslt4j; includes the JAXP packages, implements the TrAX portion of that API (javax.xml.transform....), and includes xerces.jar from &xml4j;, which implements the parser portion of the API (javax.xml.parser....).

faq.title: Chaining transformations
faq.q: How do you chain together a series of transformations?"

a.p: &xslt4j; supports two strategies for chaining together a series of transformations such that the output of each transformation provides input for the next transformation.

ul.li: For each transformation in the series, you can set one SAX ContentHandler to process the input, and another ContenHandler to process the output.
You can also set up a series of parent-child relationships between an XMLReader and one or more XMLFilters.

a.p: For the details and links to examples, see Using transformation output as input for another transformation.

faq.title: Speeding up transformations
faq.q: What can I do to speed up transformations?

a.p: In the ongoing development of &xslt4j;, enhancing performance is the primary goal of the &xslt4j; team. Here are some preliminary suggestions for you to keep in mind as you set up your applications:

ul.li: Use a Templates object (with a different Transformers for each transformation) to perform multiple transformations with the same set of stylesheet instructions (see Multithreading).
Set up your stylesheets to function efficiently.
Don't use "//" (descendant axes) patterns near the root of a large document.
Use xsl:key elements and the key() function as an efficient way to retrieve node sets.
Where possible, use pattern matching rather than xsl:if or xsl:when statements.
xsl:for-each is fast because it does not require pattern matching.
Keep in mind that xsl:sort prevents incremental processing.
When you create variables, <xsl:variable name="fooElem" select="foo"/> is usually faster than >xsl:variable name="fooElem"><xsl:value-of-select="foo"/></xsl:variable>.
Be careful using the last() function.
The use of index predicates within match patterns can be expensive.
For the ultimate in server-side scalability, perform transform operations on the client. For examples, see appletXMLtoHTML and get-todo-list.

faq.title: NoClassDefFound errors
faq.q: I'm getting a NoClassDefFound error. What has to be on the class path?

ol.li: xalan.jar and xerces.jar (or the XML parser you are using) must always be on the class path.

To run the samples in the samples subdirectories, xalansamples.jar must be on the class path. To run the servlet (in samples/servlet), xalanservlet.jar must be on the classpath along with the javax.servlet and javax.servlet.http packages. Sun distributes the javax.servlet packages in the JSWDK servlet.jar file.

To run extensions (including the samples in samples/extensions), bsf.jar, and bsfengines.jar must be on the class path. To run extensions implemented in JavaScript, js.jar must also be on the class path. For information on what you need to run extensions implemented in other scripting languages, see Supported languages.

To run applications that use the &xslt4j; version 1 API, you must put xalanj1compat.jar on the classpath, recompile the application, and be sure xalanj1compat.jar is on the classpath at run time (see Using the &xslt4j; version 1 API).

a.p: For more information, see Setting up the system class path.

faq.title: Stylesheet validation
faq.q: How do I validate an XSL stylesheet?

a.p: An XSL stylesheet is an XML document, so it can have a DOCTYPE and be subject to validation, right?

The XSLT Recommendation includes a DTD Fragment for XSL Stylesheets with some indications of what you need to do to create a complete DTD for a given stylesheet. Keep in mind that stylesheets can include literal result elements and produce output that is not valid XML.
You can use the xsl:stylesheet doctype defined in xsl-html40s.dtd for stylesheets that generate HTML.
